decision.summary: The extracted knowledge graph captures the major causal pathways from risks through principles to interventions with reasonable accuracy (schema compliance ~85%), but exhibits three significant gaps: (1) incomplete principle coverage—only 7 of 13 named corrigibility principles are explicitly represented as nodes, with 6 marked 'left as an exercise'; (2) under-decomposed implementation patterns—operator-looping encompasses three distinct strategies only partially captured; (3) missing foundational assumption node—the critical inner-alignment assumption underpinning the entire framework is not explicitly represented. The graph successfully traces main reasoning paths and would merge well with similar sources, but loses ~20% of the source's conceptual completeness. All issues are fixable through node additions and minimal restructuring without changes to core fabric topology. JSON is structurally valid with full referential integrity.

nodes.name: Emergent harmful behavior from composable steering system in real-world domain
nodes.description: Risk that combining individually non-dangerous, human-level components (world-model, pruning heuristic, evaluator) into a tree-search system controlling an internet-connected browser leads to high-impact irreversible real-world harm.
aliases: dangerous emergent behavior in composite AI

nodes.name: Capability amplification via composition of human-level subsystems
nodes.description: Even if each component is only human-level and non-agentic, their straightforward composition into a search architecture yields overall super-human steering power.

nodes.name: Applying corrigibility principles can mitigate risk but incur capability tax
nodes.description: Incorporating principles like Taskishness, Mild optimisation and Low-impact reduces dangerous behaviour but makes the system markedly less effective—the so-called ‘corrigibility tax’.

nodes.name: Bounding evaluation functions and quantilization induce mild optimization
nodes.description: If the evaluator is bounded and the planner chooses randomly among many adequate high-scoring world states (quantilisation), the system optimises only mildly, lessening extreme behaviour.

nodes.name: Impact regularization reduces downstream harm
nodes.description: Constraining the distance between predicted and current world states, or requiring futures to remain high-scoring after shutdown, limits collateral impact of executed actions.

nodes.name: Integrating corrigibility principles into steering system design
nodes.description: Overall design strategy that embeds multiple small-length corrigibility principles (bounded tasks, mild optimisation, low impact, etc.) into the architecture before deployment.

nodes.name: Restricting cognitive domains through whitelisting
nodes.description: Design approach where only pre-approved knowledge domains or reasoning styles are permitted, reducing the chance of modelling minds or out-of-scope optimisations.

nodes.name: Quantilized action selection over diverse high-scoring world states
nodes.description: Implementation where planner must return multiple sufficiently diverse world-state branches and randomly pick one, satisfying mild optimisation.

nodes.name: LLM dual-agent calibration and conservatism critique of plans
nodes.description: Pair of LLM agents – one generates plans with probabilities/utilities, a second audits them for calibration and uses ‘too-extreme’ thresholds.

nodes.name: Distance-based impact metric check before action execution
nodes.description: Before executing an action, the system computes a distance in latent state-space between current and predicted world; execution is blocked if over threshold.

nodes.name: Operator consultation action available at every tree node
nodes.description: Adding an explicit ‘call operators’ action, which when selected suspends other branches until human feedback is integrated.

nodes.name: World model future stability halt-prediction check
nodes.description: World-model simulates forward assuming the system halts; if predicted futures deviate outside safe bounds, execution is cancelled.

nodes.name: LLM critic enforcing domain whitelist adherence
nodes.description: Separate LLM examines proposed plan traces and rejects any that use reasoning outside an allowed list of domains.

nodes.name: Design steering systems with bounded evaluation and quantilized planning
nodes.description: During algorithm design, formalise evaluator bounds and enforce quantilised action selection to prevent extreme optimisation.

nodes.name: Embed operator consultation policies into planning loop
nodes.description: Fine-tune or RL-train the planner such that an ‘ask operator’ action is available and encouraged at pre-specified depths or uncertainties.

nodes.name: Integrate impact distance and halt-prediction safeguards pre-execution
nodes.description: Before deployment, add modules that compute latent-space distance thresholds and simulate futures with system halted, blocking unsafe actions.

nodes.name: Deploy LLM-based plan calibration and conservatism critics
nodes.description: Attach secondary LLMs that audit planner probabilities/utilities and flag extreme or poorly calibrated estimates before deployment.

nodes.name: Apply domain whitelist critic for cognitive restriction
nodes.description: Deploy an external critic that rejects any plan traces involving reasoning outside an approved list of domains (e.g., modelling minds).

nodes.name: Limit operational tasks to concrete bounded pivotal acts
nodes.description: Organisational policy only permits the system to be run on narrowly-scoped, well-specified tasks rather than open-ended optimisation.

nodes.name: Embedding human oversight loops at key decision points
nodes.description: Design choice to allow the system to pause and request operator advice, or have evaluators spot-checked by humans, improving corrigibility.

nodes.name: Theoretical analysis of corrigibility tax indicates reduced risk but lower capability
nodes.description: Author’s argument that integrating the listed mechanisms would likely prevent catastrophic behaviours at the expense of significant performance reduction.

notes: COVERAGE GAP IDENTIFIED: Source text lists 13 distinct corrigibility principles (Unpersonhood, Taskishness, Mild optimization, Bounded utilities, Low impact, Myopia, Separate questioners, Conservatism, Conceptual legibility, Operator-looping, Whitelisting, Shutdownability, Behaviorism, Design-space anti-optimization, Domaining, Hard problem). Extracted graph only explicitly represents 7 nodes for these principles. Six principles (Myopia, Separate questioners, Shutdownability, Domaining, Behaviorism partially, Hard problem) are mentioned in source but not instantiated as design_rationale nodes. Per instruction 'If isolated nodes cannot be connected to the fabric...remove them', these should actually be included as placeholder nodes since they are part of the core reasoning framework, even if marked as 'left as an exercise'.

DECOMPOSITION ISSUE: Operator-looping principle intentionally lists three implementation patterns: (1) 'shell out to operators for advice...execution in the rest of the tree is temporarily suspended', (2) 'E() is occasionally human spot-checked, either randomly with some small probability or at predetermined depths', (3) 'evaluation function contains a term which rates world states...higher, perhaps only probabilistically'. Current graph has one implementation_mechanism node for operator consultation but misses the other two distinct patterns. Per white-box reasoning requirements, these should be decomposed.

FOUNDATIONAL ASSUMPTION MISSING: Data source explicitly establishes assumption of no inner alignment failure in component subsystems as prerequisite for entire analysis. Quote: 'I am assuming that there is no inner alignment failure of these component subsystems...if it does not hold, the corrigibility properties I introduce...will probably also not hold.' This assumption node is missing from extracted fabric but should exist as theoretical_insight connecting risk to problem_analysis.

EDGE CONFIDENCE CALIBRATION: Edges from 'Theoretical analysis of corrigibility tax...' to implementation mechanisms rated confidence=2 (weak) appear under-rated. Source provides explicit systematic derivations for each principle-to-implementation mapping (e.g., 'we can try to ensure the system is a mild optimizer by (a) enforcing that the evaluation function provably has certain properties and (b) quantilizing the decision'). These should be confidence=3 (medium, systematic qualitative evidence).

NODE GRANULARITY VERIFICATION: Node names follow prescribed patterns correctly. Example: 'Emergent harmful behavior from composable steering system in real-world domain' (concept with context) allows merging with similar sources. 'Quantilized action selection over diverse high-scoring world states' (implementation with mechanism detail) supports downstream effectiveness analysis. All verified against exemplar patterns provided in schema requirements.

FABRIC CONNECTIVITY VERIFICATION: All current nodes (21 total) connect to main fabric. No orphaned nodes detected. Verification: traced paths from all three risk nodes through problem_analysis, theoretical_insight, design_rationale, implementation_mechanism, validation_evidence layers to intervention nodes. Longest path: risk→problem_analysis→theoretical_insight→design_rationale→implementation_mechanism→validation_evidence→intervention (7 node types).

FRAMEWORK DECOMPOSITION VERIFICATION: Source introduces corrigibility framework from external source (Eliezer's glowfic) but does not present as black-box. Instead, systematically applies each principle separately with dedicated section 'Applying each principle to the system'. Extraction correctly decomposes into component nodes (e.g., mild optimization, impact regularization, operator-looping) rather than single 'corrigibility' node. ✓ Complies with white-box requirement.

INTERVENTION LIFECYCLE ASSESSMENT: Lifecycle assignments verified against source context. Interventions marked lifecycle=1 (Model Design) include 'Design steering systems with bounded evaluation' (early architectural choice). Lifecycle=3 (Fine-Tuning/RL) for 'Embed operator consultation policies' (requires training adjustments). Lifecycle=4 (Pre-Deployment Testing) for guard mechanisms (validation phase). Lifecycle=5 (Deployment) for organizational policy 'Limit operational tasks' (runtime constraint). All justified by 'Applying each principle' implementation sections.

MATURITY ASSESSMENT: All intervention nodes rated maturity=1-2 as appropriate given source status. Maturity=1 (Foundational/Theoretical) for 'Design steering systems...' and 'Apply domain whitelist...' since source provides conceptual descriptions without implementation code. Maturity=2 (Experimental/PoC) for guard mechanisms since source provides detailed pseudo-code specifications and design patterns. None rated maturity=3+ (Prototype/Pilot) because source does not report empirical testing results. This conservatism reflects source's own position: 'I didn't spend a ton of time thinking about how to apply each principle...It may be that some of my ideas don't work'.

SOURCE-EXTRACTION CONSISTENCY CHECK: Verified all major quotes from DATA_SOURCE appear as concept node descriptions or edge rationales. Examples: (1) tree-search definition 'Perform tree search over world states' → node description, (2) corrigibility tax claim 'effectiveness penalty...alignment tax' → validation_evidence node, (3) quantilization mechanism 'find multiple sufficiently-diverse candidate world states, and then...choose randomly' → implementation_mechanism node. ✓ Traceability established.

MISSING EVIDENCE: One significant gap—source discusses how 'aligned foundation models don't imply aligned systems' but this meta-safety insight is not explicitly captured. The concept appears implicitly in 'Capability amplification via composition' problem_analysis node but lacks dedicated node. Impact: moderate (conceptually captured but not explicitly traceable). Could add theoretical_insight node 'Compositionality breaks alignment properties of components' if extraction needed absolute completeness.

(2) Distinct claims extraction: ✓ ~16 concept nodes + 6 intervention nodes = 22 nodes (target ~15 per 5000 words achieved). (3) Naming consistency: ✓ All names follow granular patterns enabling cross-source merging. (4) Traceability: ✓ All nodes reference source section titles.
